anyone else going?
Why would you want to embed media via QuickTime if you have video and audio?
Maybe you want to use those totally useful "3D" QuickTime things where you can rotate the view
You mean like you can do with <canvas>?
looks questioningly at othermaciej
pardon?
Why would you want to embed media via QuickTime if you have video and audio?
(in reference to a mailing list post of your from a few hours ago)
1) if you want to target browsers that don't have <video> yet
2) if you want to target browsers that don't support your codec of choice in <video>

3) if you want to embed content types that are supported by the QuickTime plugin but not any browser's <video> or <audio> because they are not strictly speaking either video or audio, such as QuickTime VR content or Quartz Composer content

Yes, but in the context of the thread we're talking about <iframe sandbox>.  I'm pretty sure all browsers that support that would support <video> . . . and with any luck they'll also have settled on a common codec.
Okay, I guess.
just tryin' to answer your question
I am not saying I <3 the QuickTime plugin
4) Maybe you hate your users and want to make their browsers slow and crashy
Nah, it would be easier to use Flash then.
As one participant in this conversation can attest, judging by his recent fascinating post to public-html today.  :)
somehow managed to get Flash consistently crashing Linux Chrome, when Chrome is supposed to be immune to plugin crashes.
Maybe it's a feature
disables plugins in his main browser, and has a different browser that he uses almost solely for Flash sites
Philip`, me too, but only because plugins don't seem to work with my Linux Chrome yet.
If YouTube used <video>, I'd be set.
prays.
I wonder what the status on <video>-in-YouTube is.  Sadly, I imagine it's "shelve it until <video> is actually better".
imagines a service that takes a non-<video> video as input and gives a <video> <source> as output
